Quantomatic

Quantomatic is a tool (or really, a collection of tools) that provides machine-support for reasoning with diagrammatic languages. The main tool QuantoDerive is a derivation editor. It allows users to draw diagrams and build up proofs using graph rewrite rules. It's easier to show you what that means, so download it and follow along. Sorry no Windows version yet. :(

Download for OS X Download for Linux GitHub Project »

Quick Start

Setup

The only thing you will need to have installed is the Java Runtime version 6 or later (which is also sometimes called version 1.6). Older versions of OS X come with Java pre-loaded, but for Lion or later, you will need to install it yourself. On Linux, you should be able to install Java using your package manager. To confirm it is set up correctly, check the output of java -version from the terminal.

For Linux: download the Linux bundle above, extract anywhere, and run quanto-derive.sh, either from the terminal or by double-clicking it in your file browser.

For OS X: download the OS X bundle above and extract it. The first time you run the Mac app on OS X Lion or later, you may need to run it by right-clicking, and clicking on Open, at which point it will complain about coming from an unknown developer. Allow it to open, and you should be able to run it as usual from then on.

From source: To build QuantoDerive from source, you will need: Java 6 or above, standard GNU developer tools (make, gcc, etc.), git, sbt, and Poly/ML. You will then need to clone Quantomatic, and its dependant library isaplib into the same directory, build the Quantomatic core using the Makefile, and build/run the frontend using sbt.

git clone git://github.com/Quantomatic/isaplib.git
git clone git://github.com/Quantomatic/quantomatic.git -b integration
cd quantomatic/core
make
cd ../scala
sbt run

You will see a number of options once sbt run is complete. Choose QuantoDerive.

A sample project

To start experimenting with QuantoDerive, you can clone the sample project from GitHub or download it as a zip file.

Download zip Clone from GitHub »

Once you clone (or download and unzip) the sample project, open it in QuantoDerive with File > Open Project... by selecting (or navigating to) the directory in the file browser and clicking Open.

From there, try opening graphs, rules, and derivations, and...experiment! See what happens when you click on the white dots in a derivation (these are called "proof heads") and add some rewrite rules with the Rewrite panel. Install simplification procedures (or "simprocs") by opening them and clicking . These will then become available when you click in the Simplify panel of the derivation editor.
